mortality.note: Deaths from combat, massacres, disease. Napoleon sent 40,000 troops to restore slavery. Most died of yellow fever. Haitian resistance ultimately succeeded.

rationales.systematic_intensity: 40,000 troops deployed. Mass executions, drownings (noyades). Dogs used against prisoners. Systematic campaign.
rationales.profit: Entire purpose was to restore slavery and sugar plantation profits. Saint-Domingue was France's richest colony.
rationales.ideology: Racial hierarchy assumed, but primarily economic motivation. Napoleon reinstated slavery in French colonies.
rationales.complicity: French state, military, plantation class. Europe's other powers watched. Haitian independence ignored diplomatically for decades.

analysis.pattern_note: Napoleon's attempt to restore slavery after Haitian Revolution. General Leclerc and later Rochambeau used extreme brutality - mass drownings, dog attacks, executions. France demanded 'independence debt' from Haiti until 1947. First successful slave revolution, but France never acknowledged the atrocities. Shows profit motive can drive attempted re-enslavement.
warning_signs: Former enslaved people seen as 'property' to reclaim
Massive military force deployed against civilians
analysis.root_causes: Sugar profits, Napoleon's imperial ambitions, racial ideology, fear of successful Black revolution spreading

sources.title: Avengers of the New World: The Story of the Haitian Revolution
sources.author: Laurent Dubois
